Title: Healthy Families, Healthy Communities - Change 4 Life Award
Description:
The provision of a Healthy Families, Healthy Communities - Change 4 Life Health Service (the 'Service') in the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, and the City of Westminster (the 'Authorities').
The Integrated Commissioning Department of the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea and the City of Westminster have commissioned Family Action to deliver a Change4Life service. The overall aim of the service is to support children and young people to be happy and healthy in all settings where they live, learn and play.

The Provider shall meet the specific aims of the Service which are to:

- Improve the local food environment and increase access to healthy food across local settings
- Ensure consistent messages about healthy lifestyles are promoted across all local settings 
- Provide incentives for local organisations and businesses to improve practice in relation to how they promote healthy eating and physical activity
- Increase opportunities for children, young people and families to keep active and build physical activity into their day to day lives 
- Build the capacity of local organisations to introduce sustainable actions to promote children's health and well-being
- Increase engagement of children, young people and families in the planning and design of activities to create healthier neighbourhoods/local environments 
- Contribute to local efforts to reduce childhood obesity and unequal health outcomes
- Maximise the local reach and impact of the Change4Life social marketing campaign 
- Improve the take-up of the Healthy Start scheme for eligible Service Users
- Promote the importance of recommended vitamin supplements for all pregnant or breastfeeding women and children under 5 and manage the Healthy Start Vitamins programme.

The Contracting Authority at is absolute discretion to extend the contract period from three (3) years by a period of up to two (2) years in aggregate.
The contract value includes the two year extension option for both Westminster City Council and the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea.

Description:
Cumbria County Council are inviting submissions for the provision of the Children and Families Support Service.

Title: Early Years Coordination Service
Description:
Staffordshire Children's Centres are seeking to deliver an integrated approach for under 5's: connecting all families to what they need in the community and improving outcomes for children and families based upon two key principles:

A quality offer for all accessed through:
a.	Information, advice and guidance 
b.	Good universal services 
Extra support for those who need it by providing:
c.	Effective early help for those at risk
d.	Protection for the most vulnerable families

The national core purpose of Sure Start Children's Centres is to improve outcomes for young children and their families, with a particular focus on those in greatest need. They work to make sure all children are properly prepared for school, regardless of background or family circumstances. They also offer support to parents. The full copy of the core purpose for Children's Centre's can be found at 
http://www.foundationyears.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2011/10/Core_purpose_of_Sure_Start_Childrens_Centres.pdf 

To lead the Children's Centre offer in the district there is a need for an early years coordination service to provide a coordinator and administrative support. 

The Early Years Coordination Service is a critical function within the model. This service currently consists of an Early Years Coordinator and an administrative support. The roles deliver against several areas;
•	Leadership and management of the Children's Centre delivery within the district including facilitating a partnership governance board to deliver shared priorities across the district. 
•	Safeguarding for provision commissioned on behalf of the Children's Centre or within the Children's Centre venues. 
•	Marketing and Engagement of stakeholders across the district to ensure families and stakeholders are engaged in the model and families are able to access high quality provision. 
•	Inputting, analysing and sharing key data. 
•	Administrative capacity to support delivery. 

This service is the local leader for the Early Years offer and a key part of any regulatory inspections by Ofsted. The service will operate within a required framework however the delivery will be different in each given district to meet the needs of the local community. 

The service is a countywide service based within the eight districts. The contract will also be required to lead, nurture and support the development of the local leaders and ensure that they operate to a consistently high standard and provide a single point of contact for the partnership.

Title: AHS5041 - Mental Health Family and Carer Support Services

The service will have a clear focus on enabling the carers to maintain a balance between their caring duties and their own personal life, as set out in national strategies and the Tower Hamlets Carers Strategy 2016 - 2019. Title: PQ0220 - Provision of Birth Parents & Birth Family Support - AWARD
Description:
Birmingham Children's Trust requires a supplier for the provision of Birth Parent Support as detailed below under requirements / specifications. 
      
      This contract will be for a period of 12 months commencing 1st October 2019 until 30th September 2020, (unless terminated under the terms and conditions of contract) with the provision to extend for up to an additional twelve months subject to requirements, availability of funding and satisfactory compliance and performance.
      
      The service provider will be either a Registered Adoption Agency or Adoption Support Agency. 
      
      The service is to be provided for birth parents or birth family members of children who are being, or have been, adopted in Birmingham and who are referred via methods 1-6 below.
      
      The provider will receive referrals from birth parents or birth family members that have provided consent for their details to be shared, at any or some of the following points:
      
      1.  Following Child's CIC review where adoption plan is recommended
      2.  Following the decision by the Agency Decision Maker (ADM)
      3.  At the point of matching,
      4.  Following a request for a child to be relinquished,
      5.  From the Adoption Service where there is an identification of need beyond the above stages, e.g. letter box, after the adoption order has been granted.
      6.  When the requestor wishes to access the service.
      
      If you are interested in quoting please click on the following link to access Birmingham City Council's tender Portal:-. 
      https://in-tendhost.co.uk/birminghamcc/ and submit your details to register as a bidder. We will send you a log on and password so you can download the Invitation to quotation document and supporting information; your completed quote should be returned by 1200hrs on Friday 16th August 2019 using the Supplier Portal.

Title: Understanding Child Neglect - Training for staff working in Children's Early Help, Psychology and Social Care Service
Description:
The Children's Early Help Psychology and Social Care Service (CEHPSCS) uses a multi-agency approach and seeks to ensure that the practitioners working within those services are able to recognise and act on signs of neglect that affect children, young people and whole families.  The support offered to those families is intended to improve the wellbeing, health, development and safety of the children and young people, enabling them to remain within their own family.   Earlier this year Cornwall's Neglect Strategy 2016-19 was published.  This document sets out our commitment to a multi-agency approach to preventing and responding to parental neglect.  We are now looking to commission some highly experiential learning and development opportunities with a strong skills focus to support practitioners in gaining a deeper understanding of the lived experience of children and young people who experience neglect and the long term impact of this experience. The course will also support frontline staff to develop their skills in assessing parental capacity to change; recognising that sustaining change is particularly challenging for many parents. Staff will use tools such as the Salford Graded Profile to assess, review and evaluate change.           The Council uses a web-based system on the South West Portal found at www.supplyingthesouthwest.org.uk (DueNorth) to manage quote and tender processes.  New users to the system must register on this site to obtain a username and password before gaining access to the system.

All interaction with the Council in respect of this requirement will be conducted through the  DueNorth system.  In the event that you need to contact the Authority in relation to this opportunity please follow the instructions on the advert.

Title: Provision of 21st Century Children's Centre Services.
Description:
Southend-on-Sea Borough Council invites expressions of interest from suitably experienced and qualified service providers capable of providing high quality Children's Centre services for families and children throughout the borough of Southend. 
Southend has nine children's centres currently managed as a commissioned service to nine different providers.

We are looking to procure a new single delivery model which would aim to:

— Increase efficiency through joined up leadership and management and a single performance management rather than 9.

— Develop a strong single leadership and management platform to allow budgetary integration.

— Maintain strong service delivery for families whilst providing scope for improvement

— Provide opportunities to jointly bid for outside funding and a sustainable delivery model

The successful Provider will work co-operatively and pro-actively with partner organisations to deliver a full range of Children's Centre services in line with the Children's Centre Statutory Guidance. They will provide high quality local services which are economically effective and have a positive impact on children, young people and families.

The contract will be awarded to the most economically advantageous tender in terms of the criteria stated in the specifications, and in the invitation to tender document.

Southend-on-Sea Borough Council welcomes submissions from all organisational types, including the Third Sector and Charitable Trusts.

The annual contract value will be capped at a maximum of no more than 1 039 000 GBP for 2016/17.

The procurement documents are available for unrestricted and full direct access, free of charge, at: https://procurement.southend.gov.uk

Additional information can be obtained from the abovementioned address

Tenders or requests to participate must be submitted electronically via: https://procurement.southend.gov.uk

Additional information relating to this procurement is available within the tender documents. If you wish to tender for the above requirement, please register on https://procurement.southend.gov.uk

Closing date to request the documents is 12 Noon on Monday 27.6.2016.

Closing date for technical and commercial tender submission is 12 noon on Monday 11.7.2016.

Title: Support for Vulnerable Learners at Risk of Permanent Exclusion
Description:
Northamptonshire County Council is working within a joint commissioning arrangement with the East Northants Behaviour and Attendance Partnership Cluster, (hereafter BAP Cluster), to commission a Provider who will support vulnerable learners who are at risk of permanent exclusion owing to challenging behaviour displayed within school. The Council and the BAP Cluster wish to commission a Provider to work intensively with these vulnerable learners and their families to support the learners in developing ‘behaviour for learning’ and tackling issues in areas of their lives which may prompt negative behaviour.

An intervention service is required which will support children and young people aged between 5 and 16 years old, at risk of permanent exclusion from their school. The service will work with the pupil, their family and their school to ensure that the issues which impact negatively upon the child’s behaviour are addressed and that the pupil is able to consequently demonstrate ‘behaviour for learning’.

The service will be provided to a cluster of schools in the East Northants district of Northamptonshire

The service will be required from September 2016 onwards and TUPE does not apply. The Contract is to be awarded for one year, with one 12 month option to extend. For clarity, the maximum possible duration of the Contract, should the extension be taken up is two years. 

The detailed requirements are defined in the Tender documents, please  formally register your interest in this opportunity to access the tender documentation.
Additional Text: RE: Invitation to Tender for the provision of Support for Vulnerable Learners at Risk of Permanent Exclusion (Project Id: DN119856). We can now confirm that the Contract has been awarded to Family Action.

Title: Breakfast Clubs PLEASE NOTE THE FUNDING AVAILABLE FOR THIS PROJECT IS £26 million including VAT
Description:
The breakfast club programme will contribute to improvements in the health and education of children by encouraging innovation and supporting at least 1,500 state-funded primary, secondary and special schools and Pupil Referral Units (PRUs) to deliver self-sustaining and accessible breakfast clubs. It will target the most disadvantaged schools with a focus on Opportunity Areas to ensure support is provided to pupils who need it most. 

The programme will also include funding for an innovation project(s) to test solutions to delivery and access barriers to provision, and approaches to enhancing the education, health and wider socioeconomic benefits.

The Department will award a single contract for the delivery of the programme. Bids from a consortia and/or a lead supplier with a supply chain of sub-contractors are welcome.
Region: North East,North West,Yorkshire and the Humber,East Midlands,West Midlands,East of England,London,South East,South West

Description:

Title: Provision of Carer Support Services
Description:
Durham County Council are looking for specialist provider(s) who can deliver Carer Support Services. 

The contract has been divided into two lots. Lot 1 Under the Care Act 2014 local authorities have a duty to assess a carers own needs for support regardless of whether the cared-for has eligible needs. Durham County Council would like to procure a single provider of services for adult and parent carers across County Durham to offer a wide range of advice and support to carers. Lot 2  Durham County Council would like to procure a single provider of service to ensure that young carers are not disadvantaged by their caring role and responsibilities and have the best possible chance of achieving.  The service will ensure that children and young people are protected from inappropriate caring and have the support they need to learn, develop and thrive, to enjoy positive childhoods and to achieve to their potential.

Title: Southend’s Healthwatch Service
Description:
Southend’s Integrated Commissioning Team is inviting expressions of interest to deliver its independent Healthwatch service between 1 April 2016 and 30 September 2016. As part of the contract the provider will also provide Southend’s Independent NHS Complaints Advocacy Service. Our current Healthwatch contract was commissioned in 2013 to meet the statutory requirements placed on Healthwatch and Independent NHS Complaints Advocacy Services. This contract ends 31 March 2016.

The statutory elements of The Service are set out in the Health and Social Care Act 2012 . A summary for the Healthwatch component is attached as appendix A. 

The Independent NHS Complaints Advocacy must:
Support clients with a complaint or grievance related to any aspect of healthcare as Described in the Health and Social Care Act 2012 including healthcare providers in secure environments and those which fall under the jurisdiction of the Health Service Ombudsman, such as complaints about poor treatment or service provided through NHS in England. It will ensure that individuals who are subjected to compulsory admissions to hospital under the Mental Health Act, section 3 are signposted to the appropriate IMHA service.

Annual reports produced by the current service provider for years 2013/14 and 2014/15 are attached as appendix B and C respectively.

The TUPE confidentiality agreement is provided as appendix D. Please note that this will need signing and returning to us before we are able to release the TUPE information
Attachments: Appendix E Terms and Conditions Dec 2015.doc Appendix A - A guide to the legislation affecting local Healthwatch.pdf Appendix C - Healthwatch_southend_annual_report_2014-2015.pdf Invitation for Expressions of interest healthwatch.docx Appendix D TUPE Confidentiality Form.docx Appendix B -Healthwatch_southend_annual_report_2013_2014.pdf

Title: Phase 2 - Provision of Intensive Family Support Services for Think Family (Troubled Families) - AWARD
Description:
The provision of Intensive Family Support services for Think Family (Troubled Families) in Birmingham (Phase 2). 

There are three (3) Lots for this tender, each listing the number of families that will need to be supported per year.

Lot 1 – Domestic Violence – 100 families
Lot 2 – Child Sexual Exploitation – 75 families
Lot 3 – Complex Family Transition – 100 families

The Government launched Phase 2 of the Troubled Families Programme in April 2015 with the aim of achieving outcomes for 400,000 families nationally over a 5 year period. Birmingham has been set a 5 year target to work with 14,170 families from April 2015 – March 2020.The criterion for identifying a ‘Troubled Family’ has been expanded and now includes 6 criteria. A family will need to meet 2 of the 6 criteria to qualify for a service under the Think Family programme. The 6 criteria are: 

•  Parents or children involved in crime or anti-social behaviour
•  Children who have not been attending school regularly
•  Children who need help: children of all ages, who need help, are identified as in need or are subject to a Child Protection Plan
•  Adults out of work or at risk of financial exclusion or young people at risk of worklessness
•  Families affected by domestic violence and abuse
•  Parents or children with a range of health problems

Title: Framework for Housing Related Support Services
Description: Housing Related Support Services (Accommodation Based and Floating Support) provide short term housing support to help vulnerable people to improve their quality of life and live, or continue to live, independently. Suffolk County Council are tendering for a Framework Agreement that will re-shape services to ensure they can be accessed by people across the County when they need short term housing support and focus use of available resources in a fair and transparent way. The aim is to procure a service model that will meet the following objectives: — Services that are in line with Supporting Lives Connecting Communities (SLCC) and Making Every Intervention Count (MEIC) principles and models; — Services that offer people as much control over the choice and delivery of services as possible, including uptake of personal budgets and direct payments, where appropriate; — Services that deliver measurable person-centred outcomes that will be identified and monitored; — Service costs and charges will reflect market norms; — Services that demonstrate clear service pathways for people who need short term housing support that minimise repeat admissions, make best use of limited resources and ensure fair and transparent access to available services; — Services are provided in a fair and transparent way to people with an identified short term housing support need.

the High Court (England, Wales and Northern Ireland). Any such action must be brought promptly.’

Title: Specialist 1:1 Mentoring Support
Description: There are times in a child or young person's life when mentoring support may be needed for those facing significant emotional and behavioral challenges for a variety of reasons. These children and young people can be hard to reach with specific vulnerabilities and can have a lack of engagement with statutory services. This service will be a framework agreement to deliver specialist 1:1 mentoring support.

Title: Family Link Workers
Description:
Title of Tender Opportunity:  Family Link Workers

Project Scope:  
	
The Family Link Worker Service

Dorset Council is seeking a suitably qualified and experienced Provider to deliver a Family Link Worker service across the Dorset Council area and who is committed to working in partnership with the local authority to continue the transformation of local public sector service delivery that embraces the concept that early help is everybody's responsibility and that all services take a whole family approach in supporting families with multiple and complex needs. The service needs to be effective and efficient in terms of both service delivery and management.
	
The service may be provided to a family as a whole or to specific members of that family, as part of a whole family plan. These families will generally have the most intensive and complex needs.

Family Link Workers - Definition 

Family Link Workers are one element of a graduated service delivery model. At the request of a Lead Professional a Family Link Worker will provide short-term, intensive, hands on support, assistance, direction and information to eligible families who need the most intensive level of support.  (A Family Link Worker's piece of work will contribute to the Lead Professional's family action or delivery plan - it will not be a stand-alone piece of work.)

Family Link Workers - Purpose 

The purpose of using a Family Link Worker is to engender the family's independence, improved functioning and resilience as well as that of individual family members. The intervention of a Family Link Worker needs to contribute to at least one of the outcomes that Dorset wants to see for its residents.  

Family Link Workers' agreed pieces of work need to either directly deliver or contribute to the achievement of outcomes for whole families; the individuals or groupings within a family they are allocated to.
Contact Address 2: South Walks House, South Walks Road
